title: 112_hr911
content: The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011, also known as the "Spectrum Inventory of Broadband Spectrum," amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to include a new section for inventorying broadband spectrum. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 requires the Assistant Secretary and the Commission to inventory each broadband radio spectrum band in the United States, including authorized radio services, users, activities supported, and total spectrum amount. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 mandates the inventory of broadband radio spectrum bands in the US, including details on spectrum allocation, users, devices, and usage patterns. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 requires detailed information on spectrum allocation, users, devices, and usage patterns, including contour maps illustrating coverage areas and entities offering unlicensed services. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 mandates regular updates of spectrum inventory, with reports to Congress every two years containing results of the inventory conducted. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 requires regular updates of spectrum inventory, with reports to Congress every two years containing recommendations on frequency bands. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 mandates regular updates of spectrum inventory, with recommendations on frequency bands for reallocation or shared access. The inventory must be made available to the public on an Internet website by March 31, 2012, with updates posted within 30 days of each update. There is a national security exception that requires notification by the agency head. The Spectrum Inventory and Auction Act of 2011 requires regular updates of spectrum inventory to be publicly available, with a national security exception for withholding information that could be detrimental to national security. The agency head must provide publicly releasable information, a summary description of classified national security information, and a classified annex to the Assistant Secretary. The classified annex contains information withheld from public disclosure and must be provided to Congress. Prior to any public release of the inventory conducted under subsection (a), the Assistant Secretary and the Commission must consult with the National Security Council and allow them 30 days to review the information before release. The Assistant Secretary and the Commission must consult with the National Security Council before releasing any inventory information to the public. The National Security Council has 30 days to review the information and identify data that should not be made public due to national security concerns. The Assistant Secretary and the Commission are required to use existing resources for the inventory and only request additional information if necessary. SEC. 3. VOLUNTARY INCENTIVE AUCTION REVENUE SHARING. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include voluntary incentive auction revenue sharing provisions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions for voluntary incentive auction revenue sharing, allowing licensees to relinquish spectrum usage rights for new licenses or unlicensed use, with proceeds shared through a competitive bidding system determined by the Commission. The Commission will deposit in the Treasury any proceeds not shared with a licensee who voluntarily relinquishes licensed spectrum usage rights. The Commission may treat a deposit as proceeds if a bidder in a competitive bidding system voluntarily relinquishes spectrum usage rights. The Commission's authority to auction such rights is contingent on completing a broadband spectrum inventory. The Federal Communications Commission must establish rules for voluntary incentive auction revenue sharing within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. This is in accordance with the Communications Act of 1934. The Federal Communications Commission is prohibited from reclaiming frequencies of broadcast television licensees or any other licensees on an involuntary basis under certain sections of the Communications Act of 1934. The FCC's auction authority under the Communications Act of 1934 is extended from 2012 to 2020.
